The Key Laboratory of Advanced Materials of Ministry of Education School of Materials Science and Engineering Tsinghua University Beijing 100084 China Graphical abstract CeO2/WO3-TiO2 (CeWTi) and Nb2O5-CeO2/WO3-TiO2 (NbCeWTi) catalysts were prepared by a sol-gel precipitation method. Both the catalysts exhibit high selective catalytic reduction of NO x with NH3 (NH3-SCR) activities at 270–500 °C. The sulfur tolerances of the catalysts were evaluated at 270 °C by adding H2O and SO2 in the feeding gas and NbCeWTi exhibited a significantly improved resistance. The thermogravimetric (TG) and mass spectrographic (MS) results indicated that much less sulfates formed on NbCeWTi and existed mainly in the form of ammonium hydrogen sulfate species which protected Ce x+ active sites effectively from attacking of SO2. According to the results of temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD), H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) and SO2 oxidation, loading niobia on CeWTi inhibited the SO2 oxidative adsorption and SO3 production which basically reduced sulfur poisoning of the catalyst. Additionally, the niobia modification ensured the formation of nitrates from the competitive adsorption of SO2 and hereby facilitated the nitrate SCR route based on the in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectra (DRIFTS). Keywords CeWTi Nb modification NOx SO2 oxidation Adsorption Sulfate species 1 Introduction Nitrogen oxides (NO x ) produced from mobile and stationary sources have caused many environment problems such as acid rains and the photochemical smog [1–3]. Selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of NO x with ammonia is one of the most efficient technologies for the removal of nitrogen oxides [4,5]. Nowadays, the main commercial catalysts for the stationary source SCR process are V2O5-WO3-TiO2 and V2O5-MoO3-TiO2 catalysts [6], which show high efficiency at 300–450 °C and high sulfur tolerance [7,8]. However, the narrow operation temperature window and toxicity of vanadium catalysts have been widely reported which limit their application [1,9]. Therefore, much effort has been put in to develop vanadium-free catalysts [10,11]. Among them, ceria based catalysts attract considerable attention [12,13]. Ceria exhibits high oxygen storage capacity which is considered as an essential factor in SCR reaction [14–16]. In addition, ceria has also caused a large number of concerns and researches due to its nontoxicity and low cost [17,18]. However, compared with vanadium catalysts, the SO2 tolerance is a great challenge for CeO2 SCR catalysts applied in stationary sources especially at low and mediate temperatures. Many efforts have been made to improve the SO2 resistance of ceria catalysts. Yang et al. [19] found that the sulfated CeO2 catalyst had higher NH3-SCR activities than the fresh one because of its improved NH3 adsorption capacity. However, it was unpersuasive with a fresh catalyst without sufficient surface acidity. Zhang et al. [20] compared the influence of configuration of Ce-Ti based catalysts on SO2 resistance. They disclosed that NH3-SCR could still take place on inverse TiO2/CeO2 catalysts via a synergistic catalysis between surface sulfates and bulk CeO2 although the active sites were blocked by metal sulfates. They [21] also noted that the NO conversion of the sulfated CeO2 decreased with increase of sulfation temperature due to the formation of bulk cerium sulfates instead of surface sulfates. Therefore, one of the keys remains to be to protect CeO2 from attack of SO2 for the application of ceria catalysts. In order to improve the sulfur tolerance of ceria catalysts at low and mediate temperatures, the addition of solid acids, such as TiO2 [22–24], WO3 [18,25,26] and MoO3 [27,28], appears to be an effective method. It has also been reported that the addition of Nb2O5 could promote both the redox ability of ceria catalysts from the synergistic Ce-Nb effect and their sulfur resistance due to the acidic nature of Nb2O5 species [25,29–32]. Nevertheless, the mechanism of sulfur poisoning on CeO2-Nb2O5 catalysts has not been well studied. In the previous work, we reported a novel catalyst Nb-Ce/WO x -TiO2 catalyst with high deNO x performance, hydrothermal stability and sulfur poisoning resistance [25]. However, the mechanism of the sulfur tolerance was not clearly clarified. In this work, NbCeWTi mixed oxides were prepared by a sol-gel method, and its sulfur poisoning behaviors and mechanism were systematically analyzed from the perspectives of competitive adsorption of reactants, oxidation of SO2 and amounts and types of the formed sulfate species. We believed this would provide a solid basis for developing ceria mixed oxides as SCR catalysts for industrial applications. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The catalysts were prepared by a sol-gel precipitation method as we reported previously [25]. C12H7NbO24 (Aladdin, China) and Ce(NO3)3·6H2O (Aladdin, China) were dissolved in deionized water according to a Nb2O5 : CeO2 mass ratio of 1 : 5. Nitric acid (with a HNO3: Nb2O5 molar ratio of 6:1) was added to ensure the dissolution of niobium oxalate and prevent the formation of cerium oxalate precipitate. The citric acid was used as the complexing agent with a 1.5:1 ratio of the acid to metal ions including Ce3+ and Nb5+. Appropriate polyglycol was followed with the weight of 10% citric acid added. The precursors and commercial WO3-TiO2 powders (DT52 with 10 wt.% WO3 in anatase TiO2, Millennium Chemicals, France) were mixed in deionized water. The solution was sufficiently stirred in a water bath and heated at 80 °C until a porous gel was formed. The gel was dried at 110 °C in an oven overnight. The resulting product was subsequently subjected to decomposition at 300 °C for 1 h and calcination at 600 °C for 3 h in a muffle. The reference catalyst CeWTi was prepared by the same method. The poisoned catalysts were obtained by treating the catalysts in a gas flow consisting of 500 ppm NO, 500 ppm NH3, 5% O2, 200 ppm SO2, 5% H2O, 5% O2 and balanced N2 for 100 min at 270 °C and were denoted as NbCeWTi-S and CeWTi-S. The nominal compositions and BET surface areas of the catalysts were listed in Table 1 . 2.2 Activity measurement The NH3-SCR activity measurement was carried out in a fixed bed reactor with 200 mg powder catalyst (40–60 mesh). The reaction gas mixture consisted 500 ppm NO, 500 ppm NH3, 5% O2, 5% H2O (when used), and N2 in balance. The gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) was 80,000 h−1. The feed and product concentrations were measured by a Nicolet 380 infrared (IR) spectrometer (Thermo Fisher, USA) at 100–500 °C with an interval of 50 °C. The sulfur tolerance experiments were carried out with an emission analyzer (ecom EN-2 F, RBR, Germany). The feed gas stream consisted 500 ppm NO, 500 ppm NH3, 5% O2, 5% H2O (when used), 200 ppm SO2 (when used) and N2 in balance with a GHSV of 80,000 h−1. The NO x conversion, NH3 conversion and N2 selectivity were calculated as follows. (1) N O x c o n v e r s i o n % = [ N O ] i n + N O 2 i n - [ N O ] o u t - N O 2 o u t [ N O ] i n + N O 2 i n × 100 (2) N H 3 c o n v e r s i o n % = N H 3 i n - [ N H 3 ] o u t N H 3 i n × 100 (3) S e l e c t i v i t y % = ( 1 - 2 N 2 O o u t [ N O ] i n + N O 2 i n - [ N O ] o u t - [ N O 2 ] o u t + N H 3 i n - [ N H 3 ] o u t ) × 100 2.3 Catalyst characterization Nitrogen adsorption isotherms were measured on a JW-BK122 F (JWGB, China) instrument. All the samples were degassed at 220 °C for 1 h before the nitrogen adsorption measurements. The Brunner Emmett Teller (BET) surface area was calculated by a multipoint BET method. Thermogravimetric (TG) analyses were carried out on a Mettler STA instrument to investigate the thermal stability of sulfate species over the NbCeWTi-S and CeWTi-S catalysts. For each experiment, 20–30 mg catalyst powders were analyzed from 30 to 900 °C at a heat rate of 10 °C min−1 in N2. Mass spectrographic (MS) analyses were performed on an Omnistar 200 (Pfeiffer, Germany) instrument. MS analyses were collected to distinguish different species. 100 mg sample were pretreated at 200 °C with N2 flow for 30 min. Then the samples were cooled down to 50 °C and then ramped to 900 °C at a rate of 10 °C min−1 in N2. Temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD) experiments were performed on a Nicolet 380 infrared (IR) spectrometer (Thermo Fisher, USA). Prior to the experiment, 200 mg sample was pretreated at 200 °C in a gas flow of 5% O2/N2 for 30 min. Then the samples were cooled down to 100 °C and purged with NH3 until saturation, followed by flushing with N2 to avoid the physisorption of NH3. Afterwards, the NH3-saturated samples were ramped to 500 °C at a rate of 10 °C min−1 in N2. H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was carried out on a chemisorption analyzer (Auto Chem II 2920, American Micromeritics). H2 signals were monitored with an affiliated TCD detector. 50 mg sample was pretreated with He flow (50 ml min−1) at 500 °C for 1 h and then raised from 30 to 1000 °C at a rate of 10 °C min−1 in a 10% H2/Ar flow. The SO2 oxidation activity at 100–450 °C was measured in a fixed bed reactor with 200 mg powder catalyst (40–60 mesh) and detected by the ecom EN-2 F emission analyzer. The gas mixture included 100 ppm SO2, 5% O2 and N2 in balance, and the GHSV was 80,000 h−1. The SO2 conversion was calculated as follows: (4) S O 2 c o n v e r s i o n % = S O 2 i n - S O 2 o u t S O 2 i n × 100 In situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) was performed on a Nicolet 6700 IR spectrometer (Thermo Fisher, USA). The sample spectra were calculated by Kubelka–Munk function. The reaction atmosphere consisted of 500 ppm NO2 (when used), 500 ppm NH3 (when used), 100 ppm SO2 (when used), 5% O2 and N2 in balance. The catalyst in a diffuse reflectance IR cell was pretreated by N2 (100 ml min−1) at 500 °C for 30 min to remove traces of organic residues. Then the sample was cooled down to 270 °C. Afterward, the samples were purged with the reaction atmosphere and the spectra were collected as a function of time. 3 Results 3.1 Catalytic activity 3.1.1 NH3-SCR activity The NH3-SCR activities of the catalysts are shown in Fig. 1 . CeWTi shows a wide operation temperature window (at which above 80% NO x conversion is achieved) of 260–530 °C, with the maximum NO x conversion of 100% in Fig. 1a. Comparatively, the addition of Nb decreases the NH3-SCR activity of NbCeWTi catalyst to a small extent, with a temperature window of 280–550 °C and the maximum NO x conversion of 96%. Nevertheless, it results in less byproducts (N2O and NO2) and higher N2 selectivity (always exceeding 93%) as shown in Fig. 1c. The conversions of NH3 are almost equal to those of NO x at temperatures lower than 450 °C in Fig. 1b, indicating the consumption of NH3 as the reducing agent for NO x . The oxidation of NH3 competes with the SCR reaction as a side reaction at high temperatures. 3.1.2 Sulfur tolerance In industrial applications, the exhaust gases containing SO2 may lead to deactivation of NH3-SCR catalysts, especially for those ceria-based catalysts. Therefore, it is significant to investigate the influences of H2O and SO2 on the activity of catalysts. According to the results in Fig. S1, the NO x conversions of CeWTi and NbCeWTi catalysts exceed 80% at 270 °C, and the sulfur tolerance experiments were carried out at this temperature. As shown in Fig. 2 , the NO x conversion of CeWTi decreases significantly from 90.6%–60.9% and then a continuous decline to 51.2% occurs in the presence of SO2 and H2O. Comparatively, the activity loss of NbCeWTi is smaller with the introduction of SO2 and H2O and no further deactivation is observed during this process. Furthermore, the irreversible deactivation is much weaker for NbCeWTi catalyst with a NO x conversion of 83.5% achieved after withdrawing SO2 and H2O, while the recovered value is only 66.0% for CeWTi. Additionally, NbCeWTi catalyst exhibits with a stable NO x conversion of 82.1% after a 12 h sulfation treatment at 270 °C (Fig. S2). These results demonstrate a significantly improved sulfur tolerance of CeWTi catalyst by Nb modification. It has been widely reported that both SO2 and H2O deactivate SCR catalysts at low temperatures. In order to distinguish their influences on NbCeWTi catalyst, the transient reaction analyses were performed at 270 °C and the results are shown in Fig. 3 . The NO x conversion declines from 91.6%–84.0% when subjected to a H2O-containing reaction stream, and the activity of the catalyst is restored to the original level after withdrawing H2O. This result demonstrates that H2O does inhibit the low-temperature activity of NbCeWTi to some extent, which is a totally reversible deactivation and probably caused by the competitive adsorption of H2O that occupies active sites available for NH3 and NO [33]. Fig. 3 also shows the NO x conversions of the catalyst in presence of SO2 alone. When SO2 is added in the atmosphere, the NO x conversion decreases to 75%, indicating a more serious deactivation effect of sulfur dioxide than water steam [34]. Such a deactivation is partially irreversible since the catalytic activity does not come back to the original level by removing SO2. The co-existence of H2O intensifies this sulfur deactivation, resulting in 71.0% and 83.5% NO x conversion after adding and withdrawing SO2 and H2O, respectively. 3.2 TG and MS results TG was used to identify the sulfate species on the poisoned catalysts. As shown in Fig. 4 , the mass losses of the poisoned catalysts are divided roughly into five stages. The mass loss at stage A (30–200 °C) is assigned mainly to the decomposition of water molecules in the samples. Previous studies [35–37] discovered that pure (NH4)2SO4 starts to decompose at about 200 °C and is generally converted to NH4HSO4 at temperatures lower than 250 °C. The decomposition of pure NH4HSO4 occurs at higher temperatures (320–450 °C), which was verified by our work in Fig. S3. According to our previous study [38], the catalytic decomposition of NH4HSO4 over vanadium catalysts starts at about 200 °C and is generally converted to NH4HSO4 at temperatures lower than 250 °C. As the sulfur tolerance experiments were performed at 270 °C, it is reasonable to suggest that the mass loss at stage B (200–450 °C) mainly contains the decomposition of NH4HSO4 [39–41]. As listed in Table 2 , the amount of ammonium hydrogen sulfate deposits almost doubly on NbCeWTi compared with that on CeWTi. It was reported in the literatures [42–44] that the decomposition of Ce(SO4)2 occurs in two steps with Ce2(SO4)3 as an intermediate. Hence, the mass losses at stage C (450–600 °C) and stage E (750–900 °C) are ascribed to the decomposition of cerium (IV) sulfate [20,42,45] and cerium (III) sulfate [12,46], respectively, as confirmed by the data in Fig. S4 and Table S2. The addition of niobia inhibits the formation of cerium sulfate to a great extent as listed in Table 2. The decomposition of pure Ti(SO4)2 to TiO2 occurs at 550–660 °C in Fig. S5 [47], and that of titanium sulfate in the DT-52 support is delayed to 600–750 °C in Fig. S6, corresponding to the mass loss at stage D. Thus, besides cerium sulfates, a large amount of titanium sulfates form on CeWTi-S. On the other hand, much less cerium sulfates and especially titanium sulfates are generated on NbCeWTi-S. Instead, the sulfates on the Nb-modified catalyst exist mainly in the form of ammonium hydrogen sulfate. It should be noted in Fig. 4 that the fresh catalysts also have mass loss in different stages B, D and E due to the interactions between metal oxides (CeO2 and Nb2O5) with sulfates originating from the DT52 material. The mass loss at stage E (750–900 °C) for the fresh NbCeWTi is larger than that for CeWTi, which could be related to the decomposition of Nb2O5 material as confirmed in Fig. S6. After subtracting the value of the fresh NbCeWTi, the mass loss at this stage for NbCeWTi-S can be attributed mainly to the decomposition of cerium (III) sulfate to ceria as mentioned above. To further verify the assignments of sulfate species on the poisoned catalysts, their temperature-programmed decomposition behaviors were monitored by MS. Fig. 5 shows the evolutions of the SO2 (64 m/e) and NH3 (17 m/e) signals in a temperature range 100–900 °C. As shown in Fig. 5a, the NH3 desorption peak centered at around 340 °C is ascribed to the decomposition of (NH4)HSO4 to NH3 [35,48]. The temperature range 250–500 °C is somewhat delayed by 50 °C compared with stage B in Fig. 4, which is probably caused by the specific locations of the thermocouple in different instruments. More NH3 is produced over NbCeWTi-S, which is consistent with the TG results that more ammonium hydrogen sulfate is deposited on this catalyst. It is noted that almost no SO2 was detected by MS at this stage, which can be attributed to the recombination of released SO2 with surface metal oxides [20,49]. A broad SO2 desorption peak appears at around 578–594 °C in Fig. 5b resulting from the decomposition of (NH4)2S2O7 which is produced from NH4HSO4 [48]. It can be seen that the SO2 desorption peak at around 340 °C is stronger on the Nb-modified catalyst, which is again in a good accordance with the TG results that more ammonium hydrogen sulfate is deposited on this catalyst. Another distinct SO2 peak at around 780 °C is associated with the decomposition of metal sulfates, especially for cerium sulfates and titanium sulfates, which is much more intense on CeWTi-S. This may explain the continuous deactivation of CeWTi catalyst upon exposure to sulfur dioxide with time in Fig. 2. 3.3 Surface acidity NH3-TPD was applied to measure the amounts and strengths of acid sites on the catalysts, and the results are shown in Fig. 6 and Table 3 . For the fresh catalysts, the addition of niobia reduces the amount of weak acid sites to a small extent, probably due to a decrease in the surface concentration of ceria as Lewis acid sites [18]. Meanwhile, it increases the amount of medium strong acid sites significantly with Nb2O5 serving as Brønsted acid sites [50], which was verified by in situ DRIFTS of NH3 desorption in Fig. S7. After the sulfation treatment, the surface acidity increases for both the poisoned catalysts. CeWTi-S owns more medium strong acid sites provided by metal sulfate species [20]. It is interesting to find that more ammonia is desorbed on the sulfated catalysts at low temperatures, which should be ascribed to the extra release of NH3 from decomposition of NH4HSO4. 3.4 Redox property 3.4.1 H2-TPR H2-TPR experiments were performed to investigate the redox properties of the catalysts. In order to minimize the influences of surface sulfates especially ammonium hydrogen sulfate, all the catalysts were pretreated in He at 500 °C for 1 h. According to the TG (Fig. 4) and MS (Fig. 5) results, the deposited NH4HSO4 decomposes nearly completely in a similar inert atmosphere (N2), while most of metal sulfates remain after the pretreatment. The H2 consumption of different reduction peaks in Fig. 7 was given by the chemisorption analyzer, and the results are listed in Table 4 . For the fresh catalysts, the sharp reduction peak centered at 521–525 °C is attributed to the reduction of surface/sub-surface oxygen of ceria [17,18,26]. The broad peak at around 610–630 °C is ascribed to the reduction of WO3 to WO2.9 [51]. Another broad peak at 780–840 °C corresponds to the overlapped reduction of lattice oxygen from bulk ceria and WO2.9 to WO2 [18,26,51,52]. Clearly, the loading of Nb2O5 reduces the redox property of CeWTi catalyst to a certain extent, since the H2 consumption associated with the low-temperature peak declines. The temperature of the bulk ceria reduction peak is significantly advanced from 840 to 780 °C. This phenomenon may be related to the reduction of bulk Nb2O5 to Nb2O4 [29,53]. Compared with the fresh sample, CeWTi-S has a more intense H2 consumption peak at 516 °C due to the extra contribution of reduction of sulfate species [19,21]. The reduction of cerium sulfate and titanium sulfate occurs generally at 300–650 °C [19], resulting in a significant increase in H2 consumption. Contrarily, the low-temperature H2 consumption of NbCeWTi-S even decreases, implying the formation of much less metal sulfates. These trends are in good consistence with the TG and MS results. It should be noted that the reduction of those recombined sulfates with surface metal oxides would also contribute to H2 consumption and make the interpretation of the peak 1 more complicated. The co-effect of weakened redox property of metal oxide sites and residual surface sulfates may result in a slight decrease in the H2 consumption of the peak 1 over NbCeWTi-S. 3.4.2 SO2 oxidation activity The activity for the oxidation of SO2 to SO3 is crucial for the sulfur tolerance of catalysts, and the results of two fresh catalysts are shown in Fig. 8 . Due to the facile redox cycle between Ce3+ and Ce4+ [54], CeWTi shows relatively high SO2 conversions. Over this catalyst, SO2 conversion reaches 3% at 300 °C and increases to 15% at 450 °C. According to the NH3-TPD results, the doping of niobia into CeWTi catalyst increases the surface acidity which can decrease the adsorption of SO2 on the catalyst surface. On the other hand, the redox property of the Nb-modified catalyst is weakened to some extent as shown in Fig. 7. Both these two factors result in a significant decrease in SO2 oxidation activity of NbCeWTi. The SO2 conversion over NbCeWTi is 0.5% and 1.0% at 300 and 450 °C, respectively. Obviously, the inhibited oxidation of SO2 would importantly reduce the generation of sulfates on the Nb-modified catalyst. 3.5 DRIFTS study 3.5.1 SO2 + O2 adsorption Fig. 9 shows the DRIFT spectra of adsorbed species over CeWTi and NbCeWTi catalysts in a SO2 + O2 flow at 270 °C as a function of time. As shown in Fig. 9a, several bands at 1620, 1400, 1320 and 1270 cm−1 are detected in the spectra of CeWTi. All these bands are ascribed to the sulfate species formed on the catalyst. The band at 1320 cm-1 is attributed to the asymmetric stretching frequencies of OSO species for surface sulfates adsorbed on metal oxides [20,55]. The band at 1400 cm−1 is ascribed to the sulfate species with only one SO and three SO bonds with the O atoms linked to the surface [45]. The band at 1270 cm-1 is assigned to bidentate sulfates [56,57]. The band at 1620 cm−1 is assigned to adsorb H2O from the reaction between SO2 and surface hydroxyl groups [58–60]. The band at 1400 cm−1 increases sharply in intensity with time, indicating the formation of a large amount of surface sulfate species on CeWTi. After the modification of niobia, the adsorption of SO2 and formation of sulfates are significantly inhibited as indicated by the greatly reduced intensities of the corresponding bands in the spectra in Fig. 9b. 3.5.2 Influences of SO2 on NO x /NH3 adsorption For NH3-SCR reaction, the formation of sulfates may occupy or cover the active sites and decrease the catalytic activity. Therefore, it is significant to investigate the competitive adsorption between SO2 and NO x on the active sites [58]. In this experiment, CeWTi and NbCeWTi catalysts were first exposed to 500 ppm NO + 5% O2 for 30 min at 270 °C. After then, 100 ppm SO2 was fed into the gas system, and the results are shown in Fig. 10 . When purging with NO x for 30 min, the bands at 1290 and 1606 cm−1 are clearly observed, which are assigned to monodentate nitrates and bridge nitrates, respectively [54,61–64]. After the introduction of SO2 for 30 min, the surface sulfate bands at 1400, 1320 and 1270 cm−1 are formed on both the catalysts. It is noted that the initial bands assigned to nitrate species vanish quickly on CeWTi, while those keep co-exist with the sulfate species on NbCeWTi. It is clear that SO2 occupies the Ce x + active sites resulting in a significantly reduced capacity of CeWTi for NO x adsorption. The modification of niobia could ensure the adsorption of NO and formation of nitrates upon exposure to SO2 and hereby facilitate the nitrate SCR route of ceria based catalyst at low temperatures, as confirmed by the results in Fig. 2. The influence of the pre-adsorbed sulfur species on NH3 adsorption was also investigated by an IR study. The catalysts were pretreated in 100 ppm SO2 + 5% O2 for 30 min and purged by N2 for 30 min. NH3 was subsequently introduced and the spectra were recorded in Fig. 11 . Brønsted acid sites related bands (1674 and 1447 cm−1) [65]and Lewis acid sites related bands (1601, 3387 and 3255 cm-1) [21,58] are observed for the catalysts. It can be seen that the pre-adsorbed SO x inhibits the adsorption of NH3 on Lewis acid sites to some extent. Compared with the fresh catalyst, more ammonia is adsorbed on the sulfated CeWTi since the formed metal sulfates themselves can serve as medium strong acid sites as confirmed by the NH3-TPD results. For the Nb-modified catalyst, the adsorption of NH3 changes little after the SO2 pretreatment, implying the deposition of much less sulfates. In this sense, the adsorption of NH3 in the presence of sulfates should not be responsible for the deactivation of the sulfated catalysts. 4 Discussion 4.1 SO2 oxidation and sulfate formation over the catalysts SO2 has always complicated poisoning process on cerium based NH3-SCR catalysts. Waqif et al. [66] reported that ceria is basic material for SO2 oxidative adsorption and sulfate species might preferentially form on ceria surface. First of all, it is important to reduce the SO2 oxidation activity of catalyst [67]. From the H2-TPR experiments in Fig. 7, it is known that loading of niobia reduces the redox property of CeWTi catalyst to a certain extent. Meanwhile, the increased surface acidity of NbCeWTi in Table 3 would inhibit the oxidative adsorption of SO2 [68]. As a result, the SO2 oxidation activity of the catalyst decreases significantly with the introduction of niobia in Fig. 8. Based on the DRIFTS study of SO2 + O2 adsorption in Fig. 9, the SO2 oxidative adsorption would produce sulfates on active sites. The normalized intensity and area of the band assigned to sulfate species (1400 cm−1) on different catalysts as a function of time are shown in Fig. 12 . The sulfate band reaches the maximum intensity within 20 min on NbCeWTi catalyst, indicating the quick saturation of surface sulfates. However, the sulfates species keep forming even at 30 min on CeWTi. On the other hand, much more sulfates are produced on CeWTi catalyst as reflected by the band area. Thus, the loading of niobia on CeWTi inhibits the SO2 oxidation and formation of sulfates on catalyst effectively. It has been identified by the TG and MS experiments that there are two major types of sulfates after the sulfur tolerance test at 270 °C, i.e. ammonium hydrogen sulfate and metal (cerium and titanium) sulfates. On the one hand, the reaction between the NH4 + absorbed on Brønsted acid sites and sulfate species produces ammonium hydrogen sulfate which covers the active site. Furthermore, the co-existence of H2O increases the generation rate of NH4HSO4 [39]. The decomposition of this salt occurs at about 320 °C, which is higher than the temperature at which the sulfur tolerance test was performed. Therefore, a lot of NH4HSO4 is deposited on both the sulfated catalysts. The amount of medium strong acid sites which absorb ammonia species increases significantly on NbCeWTi catalyst. In this case, more ammonium hydrogen sulfate is produced on the modified catalyst. On the other hand, CeO2 and TiO2 can form metal sulfates by reaction with the adsorbed SO3 and NH4HSO4 [54,69]. These metal sulfate species are stable and decompose at higher temperatures. CeWTi catalyst owns less medium strong acid sites and higher ability to oxidize SO2. It was estimated in the ESI that about 1.7% of ceria has been converted to cerium sulfates for CeWTi-S. The calculation process was given in Table S2. It should be noted that these cerium sulfates are formed on the catalyst surface and a part of titania adjacent to surface ceria would also be converted to titanium sulfate. As a result, CeWTi catalyst absorbs less ammonia species and forms much more metal (Ce and Ti) sulfates species. It is obvious in Table 2 that the addition of niobia inhibits the generation of metal sulfates and facilitates the reservation of ammonium hydrogen sulfate on NCeWTi-S. Ce x + active sites are protected to a great extent from attack of sulfates species with the addition of niobia and only about 0.7% of ceria were poisoned. Additionally, almost no titanium sulfates are formed on this catalyst. 4.2 Influence of SO2 adsorption and sulfate formation on NH3-SCR reaction Competitive adsorption between SO2 and NO x on CeWTi and NbCeWTi catalysts has been proved in Fig. 10. To show this more clearly, the normalized area of the band at 1606 cm−1 assigned to bridge nitrate species on different catalysts as a function of time are shown in Fig. 13 a. The nitrate band drops closely to zero within 15 min on CeWTi catalyst due to occupying of active sites by SO2. It can be consequently expected that the nitrate route at low temperatures would be greatly limited on this catalyst. On the contrary, the nitrate band remains quite strong upon attack of SO2 on NbCeWTi catalyst, indicating that the addition of niobia prevents the sulfation of active sites for NO x adsorption. It is believed to facilitate the nitrates route for NH3-SCR reaction over NbCeWTi catalyst at low temperatures. The evolution of the normalized area of the sulfate band at 1400 cm−1 was also drawn as a function of time and the results are shown in Fig. 13b. Again, a quicker saturation of surface sulfates is reached on NbCeWTi catalyst and much less sulfates are deposited, which are similar to the case in Fig. 12. This results in a co-adsorption of NO x on NbCeWTi catalyst while the competitive adsorption of SO x occupies predominantly the active sites on CeWTi catalyst. Besides the competitive adsorption of NO and SO2, the sulfates cause catalyst deactivation from two ways in NH3-SCR. On the one hand, the surface coverage with ammonium hydrogen sulfate would reduce the availability of active sites [70]. This type of deactivation is reversible to a large extent as shown in Fig. 2 because the deposited NH4HSO4 would be consumed by reacting with NO as a reducing intermediate after withdrawing the inlet SO2 [54]. On the other hand, the formation of Ce2(SO4)3 and Ce(SO4)2 cut down Ce3+/Ce4+ redox cycle so that the SCR catalytic activity continue to decline. It causes the continuous decline in the catalytic activity of CeWTi upon exposure to sulfur dioxide in Fig. 2. Obviously, the sulfur poisoning deactivation caused by metal sulfates is irreversible at low temperatures. Thus, the incomplete regeneration of the sulfated catalysts after withdrawing SO2 should be due to the deposition of ammonium hydrogen sulfate and especially metal sulfates. The corresponding deactivation mechanisms by SO2 over different catalysts are presented primarily in Fig. 14 . 5 Conclusions CeWTi and NbCeWTi catalysts were synthesized by a sol-gel precipitation method. Both the catalysts exhibited superior NH3-SCR activities at 280–530 °C. Their low-temperature sulfur tolerances were evaluated as sulfur poisoning is always critical to ceria based catalysts. Several major conclusions were drawn as below: (1) The deactivation effect of SO2 is much higher than that of H2O, and the co-existence of H2O intensifies this effect. The addition of Nb2O5 in CeWTi catalyst reduces the degree of SO2 poisoning significantly. More importantly, CeWTi exhibits a continuous decline of NO x conversion by 9.7% during a 100 min NH3-SCR reaction in a SO2 and H2O containing atmosphere at 270 °C, while NbCeWTi keeps an almost unchanged catalytic activity in this process. (2) SO2 occupies the active sites resulting in a severely inhibited NO x adsorption on CeWTi, which would be detrimental to the nitrate route for NH3-SCR reaction over ceria based catalysts at low temperatures. Such a competitive adsorption between SO2 and NO is solved to a great extent by the addition of niobia. Furthermore, the SO2 oxidation is also suppressed over the modified catalyst, which may be related to the weakened redox property and strengthened surface acidity. (3) Loading niobia on CeWTi reduces the formation of metal sulfates, protecting Ce x + from attack of sulfur dioxide. Instead, more ammonium hydrogen sulfate, which derives from the reaction between the NH4 + absorbed on Brønsted acid sites and sulfate species, has been deposited on the modified catalyst with more medium strong acid sites. This type of sulfate species can act as a reducing agent and be consumed after withdrawing SO2, making the poisoning reversible to a large extent. However, the metal sulfates are quite stable and contribute importantly to the irreversible deactivation of CeWTi catalyst. coredata.dc:description: CeO2/WO3-TiO2 (CeWTi) and Nb2O5-CeO2/WO3-TiO2 (NbCeWTi) catalysts were prepared by a sol-gel precipitation method. Both the catalysts exhibit high selective catalytic reduction of NO x with NH3 (NH3-SCR) activities at 270–500 °C. The sulfur tolerances of the catalysts were evaluated at 270 °C by adding H2O and SO2 in the feeding gas and NbCeWTi exhibited a significantly improved resistance. The thermogravimetric (TG) and mass spectrographic (MS) results indicated that much less sulfates formed on NbCeWTi and existed mainly in the form of ammonium hydrogen sulfate species which protected Ce x+ active sites effectively from attacking of SO2. According to the results of temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD), H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) and SO2 oxidation, loading niobia on CeWTi inhibited the SO2 oxidative adsorption and SO3 production which basically reduced sulfur poisoning of the catalyst. Additionally, the niobia modification ensured the formation of nitrates from the competitive adsorption of SO2 and hereby facilitated the nitrate SCR route based on the in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectra (DRIFTS).
coredata.dc:title: A comprehensive study on sulfur tolerance of niobia modified CeO2/WO3-TiO2 catalyst for low-temperature NH3-SCR
